title: If an attorney has drafted my schedules and plan in chapter 13 bk, can i handles the meetings on my own to get it confirmed?
question: I missed my meeting of creditors due to an emergency. And now my attorney is requiring almost double his original retainer to refile. I can understand that but I just dont have that and still need to file.
answers: Chapter 13 fees are regulated by the court. Your attorney cannot simple charge you double fees. Court would not approve.

There seems to be another problem with what you said other than what the other attorneys here have answered. I agree with their answers about the "dismissal".

But about the fees: your attorney can't require you to pay money after the case is filed without a court order approving additional fees and approving a direct payment. All of your assets are property of the bankruptcy estate and your income is also property of the estate. It has to be used for what your budget allows and the rest goes to the trustee. If you can pay an additional "retainer", that is extra money that has to go to the trustee, not your attorney.

If you attorney wants to apply for fees as part of the confirmation or after the confirmation, they can show the court the additional work done and those fees would ordinarily be paid through the trustee, although the court could order direct payment.

In the Eastern District (Sacramento) most of the judges would say that an additional Meeting of Creditors would be part of the anticipated work to be done on the case, but even here if the attorney tracks the time spent and shows that the time was reasonable and necessary, then the fees will be based on that. But that still wouldn't be an additional direct payment to the attorney in most cases.

Show up when you are supposed to show and up take care of your case if you are serious about getting a chapter 13 discharge.
I would have your lawyer do it. There are horror stories of things never getting filed. Alternative to BK talk to a debt collection attorney

Atty Hill is correct. We are missing some important facts. Missing your first meeting does not result in your case being dismissed unless you have failed in other parts of your case, like missing payments, etc. That said, refiling your case should not cost you double because all the creditor information and other schedules won't be changing that much. You will have to pay another filing fee of $310. If you are a multiple filer, your lawyer may need to file additional documents to reinstate the automatic stay.

In the EDCA you have to do more (or maybe less) than just miss the initially scheduled 341 meeting to have your case dismissed.
If your case is dismissed once within the year, it's possible you need a motion to extend the automatic stay, as the stay only lasts 30 days in the second by. I'd dismissed 2x or more, you have to file a motion to have a stay instituted on the creditors. All of that would explain the extra cost, and you don't have that motion.
In addition you need to update your schedules and means test.
So, yes you can represent yourself, but it's not recommended.
